info.game_comments: WE ASKED: NYT crossword puzzle editor Will Shortz.

(1, 1).clue: Van Gogh's "Self-Portrait with Pipe and Bandaged ____"

(2, 1).clue: (Dan Patrick reads the clue.)  My good friend Adam Sandler has cast me in 9 of his films, including "Grown Ups 2" in which I played a gym teacher dressed as this 1980s Celtics legend

(4, 1).clue: Almonds are an excellent source of fiber & this bone-building element--got milk?

(5, 1).clue: This Christian sacrament, a holy ceremony, is also called Eucharist

(6, 1).clue: (Will Shortz delivers the clue.)  Monday had a presidential theme; one clue was to this "supply-side fiscal policy popularized in the 1980s"

(1, 2).clue: Jonathan Buttall is thought to be Gainsborough's model for "The ____ Boy"

(2, 2).clue: In "Twilight" this author has a cameo as a customer in a diner with a veggie plate

(4, 2).clue: These biggies from the Amazon basin have many health benefits, but with their high selenium content, too many can be harmful

(5, 2).clue: A ceremony on November 19, 1863 dedicated a cemetery in this town

(6, 2).clue: (Will Shortz delivers the clue.)  On Tuesday we had some hidden Bobs; you'll find Dylan in this "classic board game with a peppermint forest"

(1, 3).clue: Seurat got to the point in "A ____ Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte"

(2, 3).clue: (Al Michaels delivers the clue.)  Well, I didn't win an Oscar playing myself in this 1996 movie but Cuba Gooding Jr. did for his performance as a wide receiver for the Cardinals

(4, 3).clue: A key ingredient in pesto, these nuts are an excellent source of vitamin E

(5, 3).clue: Vice presidents are often sent to this type of ceremony overseas; Al Gore attended Mitterrand's in 1996

(6, 3).clue: (Will Shortz delivers the clue.)  On Wednesday you had to know compound words where each half could also have "dead" before it--there was airline, seahorse & this response to "top on official stationery"

(1, 4).clue: Duchamp caused a scandal with his "Nude Descending a ____, No. 2"

(2, 4).clue: Julia Roberts played this title crusader in a 2000 film while the real woman had a cameo as a waitress

(4, 4).clue: Pistachios get their green color mostly from lutein, which is essential to this one of the 5 senses

(5, 4).clue: Giant scissors are mainly used for this type of ceremony at the grand opening of a new facility

(6, 4).clue: (Will Shortz delivers the clue.)  On Thursday we rolled the D-I-C-E, as in these, "racy books named after a Victorian garment"

(1, 5).clue: Dali gave it a name that stuck: "The Persistence of ____"

(2, 5).clue: From "Rebecca" on, this director appeared in all of his films; he sat next to Cary Grant on a bus in "To Catch a Thief"

(4, 5).clue: Have some hazelnuts before bed; they're high in this sleep-aiding amino acid that's also found in turkey

(5, 5).clue: An accolade, a ceremonial tap on the shoulder with a sword, is followed by the words "I dub thee" this

(6, 5).clue: (Will Shortz delivers the clue.)  On Friday there's no theme, so you just have to know this 10-letter "TV host who followed Jimmy Fallon on late night"

(1, 1).clue: This title character of a Coleridge poem must wander the world recounting the tale of his days at sea

(3, 1).clue: This "seasonal" palace has been called "St. Petersburg's most famous building"
(3, 1).correct response: the Winter Palace for the Romanovs

(4, 1).clue: Inducted in 1977, this American who'd been laden with gold at Munich 5 years earlier

(5, 1).clue: In 2001 General Mills bought this other Minneapolis-based baking giant for $10.5 billion; that's a lot of dough, boy

(6, 1).clue: In Acts 9 Paul gets a call from the Lord near this Syrian city

(1, 2).clue: Keats was inspired to write an ode to this bird by the song of one that nested in Charles Brown's garden

(2, 2).clue: William Blackstone called it "the great and efficacious writ, in all manner of illegal confinement"

(3, 2).clue: Lhasa's Potala Palace would be a nice place for this religious leader, who fled in 1959, to come home to, if he ever can

(5, 2).clue: Minneapolis is the home town of this pop icon; his Paisley Park Studios are about a half hour away

(6, 2).clue: Paul & Barnabas preached to big crowds in Antioch, where Acts 11 says the Disciples were first called these

(1, 3).clue: After part of "Childe Harold's Pilgrimage" was published, this lord "awoke one morning and found myself famous"

(2, 3).clue: A young pine or fir stem tossed in Highland Games

(3, 3).clue: Istana Nurul Iman, the palace of the sultan of this country, features an air conditioned stable & a mosque for 1,500 people

(4, 3).clue: 1993:This 4-time Olympic gold medalist who did much of his swimming following a dive

(5, 3).clue: Foshay Tower was Minneapolis' tallest when opened in this year; Mr. Foshay's business promptly collapsed, but the tower stands

(6, 3).clue: Paul's New Testament letters include 2 to these Greeks who gave their name to an order of classical architecture

(1, 4).clue: His first major work was "The Lay of the Last Minstrel", a poem set on & north of England's northern border

(2, 4).clue: This word for the science of baseball analytics comes from the name of a research society

(3, 4).clue: Ponder the tragic life of Crown Prince Rudolf in his lavish suite in this capital's Schonbrunn Palace

(4, 4).clue: This prince shown as a young man, later chairman of the Monegasque Swimming Federation

(5, 4).clue: Drive your toy truck to this 12-mile-long lake in the western suburbs

(6, 4).clue: The lord calls Paul a "chosen vessel... to bear my name before" these non-Jews

(1, 5).clue: The play in verse about this Greek god "Unbound" is often regarded as Shelley's greatest work

(2, 5).clue: Early scientific instrument used to measure the altitude of celestial objects

(3, 5).clue: Overlooking Granada, Spain, it has a name from Arabic for "Red", probably from the bricks of the outer walls

(4, 5).clue: This U.S. champ who helped bring the swimming movie to Hollywood with films like "Bathing Beauty"

(5, 5).clue: Before the Twins, fans rooted for this minor league team named for the many locals who worked grinding flour

(6, 5).clue: Paul was born Saul in this Asia minor city around 4 B.C.

(0, 0).clue: While working for a plastics company, Don Featherstone created this iconic lawn decor, basing it on photos in National Geographic
